# MARKDOWN 

**Markdown**  is a lightweight markup language that you can use to add formatting elements to the plaintext (represents only characters of readable material but not its graphical representation ) text documents.
It is not simple like other text editors as **Microsoft** where you just click the button to formate words and phrases and the changes are visible immediately.
When you create a markdown-formatted file you add the markdown syntax to text to indicate which words and phrases should look different.

# EXAMPLE 

To indicate heading add number sign before the word (#  Heading), and to show text in bold form add double asterisks before and after that text (** ...**).

# IMPORTANCE

**Markdown** is used everywhere as it is an easy formatting language. It is used for website making, blogging, documentations, emailing and for note making.

# BASIC SYNTAX

The Markdown elements outlined in the original design document.

# 1. HEADINGS...

Use number sign before heading. There are six levels of headings. It depends upon the number of number sign you use before heading.  

If you use number sign one time before heading it will be bold and will be gradually light by the addition of number of number sign before the heading.  
- # HEADING
- ## HEADING
- ### HEADING
- #### HEADING
- ##### HEADING
- ###### HEADING

# 2. PARAGRAPHS..

To create a paragraph use blank line to separate one or more lines of text.

# 3. LINE BREAKS...

To create a line break or add new line, end the line with two or more spaces and then type return.

This is a line  
This is a new line

# 4. BOLD...

In order to bold the text, add two asterisks or two underscores before and after the text.

I love **Pakistan**  
I love __Pakistan__

# 5. ITALIC...

If you want to write text in italics use single asterisks or underscore before and after the text.

I love *Pakistan*  
I love _Pakistan_

# 6. BOLD AND ITALIC...

If you want to make text bold and italic, use three asterisks or underscores before and after the text.

I love ***Pakistan***  
I love ___Pakistan___

# 7. BLOCKQUOTES...

To create blockquote add a > in front of the paragraph.  

> I love Pakistan, as it is my dear homeland.

# 8. BLOCKQUOTES WITH MULTIPLE PARAGRAPHS...

Blockquotes can contaib multiple paragraphs. Add a > on blank line before the paragraph.

> I love Pakistan.    
>
> I want to devote my life for my dear homeland.

# 9. NESTED BLOCKQUOTES...

Blockquotes can be nested. Add a >> before the paragraph you want to nest.

> I love Pakistan.  
> 
>> I lives in Pakistan and wants to devote my whole life the progress of my dear homeland.  
> As a Best citizen of Pakistan, it is the moral duty of every Pakistan to work for the progress of his country.

# 10. BLOCKQUOTES WITH OTHER ELEMENTS...

Blockquotes can contain other markdown formatted elements.

> ## The company's progress was outclass:  
> 
> - Revenue was above the 10 Billions $.  
> 
> - The aggregate company's profit was 5 Billion $. 

# 11. ORDERED LISTS...

To create an ordered list, add line items with numbers followed by periods. It is not necessary to follow the numerical order, But the list should start with number 1.

1. First item.
2. Second item.
3. Third item.
      1. First item. 
      1. Second item.
      1. Thid item.

# 12. UNORDERED LISTS...

In order to create an unordered list, add asterisks(*), plus (+) or dash(-) before the list.
Indent one or more items to create a nested list.

* First number
+ Second number
- Third number 
    * Indented item.
    + Indented item.

# 13. STARTING UNORDERED ITEMS WITH NUMBERS...

If you need to start an unodered list with a number followed by a period,  you can use backslah (\\) to escape 
the period.

* 1990 was a great year.  
+ 1991 was also a great year.  
- Do not forget 1993, as it was also a great year.

# 14. ADDING ELEMENTS IN THE LIST...

In order to add new element in the previous list, use four spaces or one tab before that line or element that you want to add. 
## PARAGRAPH
* Here is the first item.
+ Here is the second item.  
    Hello, everyone my name is Tahir Abbas and i am here to teach you Python.
    
- Here is the third item.

## BLOCKQUOTE

* Here is the first item.
+ Here is the second item.  
    > Hello everyboby, My name is Tahir Abbas and i am here to teach you Python.
- Here is the third item.

## CODE BLOCKS

Code are normally intended four spaces or one tab, but when they are in list use eight spaces or two tabs to intend.

* Here is the first item.
+ Here  is the second item.  
        
            <head>

               <title> Test </title>

            </head>

            
        
- Here is the third item.

## IMAGE
1. 0pen the Google Chrome.
2. Saerch nature images.  
    ![Natural scene](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
1. See and enjoy the natural beauty.

# 15. NESTING OF AN UNORDERD LIST WITHIN AN ORDERED LIST...

We can nest an unordered list within an ordered list and vice versa.

1. Here is the first item.
2. Here is the second item.  
    - Intended item.
    - Intended item.

# 16. CODE...

To denote a word or phrase as code, enclose it in single backtick ( ` ).

Here is the simple code in Python to print Hello World.

    `print("Hello World!")`

# 17. ESCAPING BACKTICKS...

If the word or phrase you want to show as a code indicate one or more backticks, you can escape it by enclosing the word or phrase in double backticks.  
- ``

`` Here is the simple Python code `print("Hello World)` to print Hello World``

# 18. CODE BLOCK...

To create code blocks, indent every line of code by one tab or four spaces and enclose it in single backticks.  

- ` 

    Putt your code here

        `


    `   <head>
         My Documents
            </head>`

# 19. HORIZONTAL RULES...

To create a horizontal rule, use three or more asterisks (***), dashes (---) or underscore(___) on a line by themselves.

- ***
- ---
- ___

# 20. LINKS...

To create a link, write the text or name of your link in square brackets [], then use parentheses () to enclose the link.  
-  Write about your link [ Put name of web your link ]( Put link here)

My favorite search engine is [GOOGLE](https://www.google.co.uk/).

## ADDING TITLES

If you want to show some text about your link, when user hover over the link add that text in enclosed strings after the link.  

- Write about your link [Put the name of web of your link here](Put the link here "Write about your link").

My favorite search engine is [GOOGLE](https://www.google.co.uk/ "This the worldwide best search engine").

## URLS AND EMAIL ADDRESSES

To turn quickly email addresses and links into links, enclose it in angle brackets.  

- < Put you link or email here>

<https://www.google.co.uk/>.  
<tahir99888plm@gmail.com>

## FORMATING LINKS

To emphasize links, add  asterisks before and after the brackets and parentheses.  
And to donate link as code add backticks (`) in the brackets.  

- Write your opinion about your link ***[ Write name of your web]( Put link of your web here.)***

I love supporting the ***[EFE](https://www.eff.org/)***.  
See the section on [`code`](#code).

# 21. ADDING IMAGE...

To add image, add an exclamation mark (!) followed by the text in square brackets and the image path in parentheses. 
![K2](images.jpg "K2 Mountain")
